transcripts.text: We got a problem.  Welcome to the video guys. So come over there and check me out if you want.  The link is in the video description.  Anyway, enough of all that.  Let's watch Adam Bolton and the media narrative get destroyed by Kevin Hurley here.

22 police officers were injured last night after violence erupted when they tried to encourage crowds to leave an unlicensed street party in Brixton in South London.  Well, joining me now is the former Metropolitan Police Chief Superintendent Kevin Hurley.  Mr Hurley, thank you for being with us.  Put this event into proportion for us, if you can.  I mean, quite often in hot weather, you do get incidents, certainly, of street parties going on long into the night, don't you?

Right, let me stop that there.  You can see him already trying to frame the narrative and take it away from what really... happened and part of the reason why things like this will only increase.  As I said in my previous video these things do happen in London and other places from time to time when it comes to street parties and the violence they bring.  But the Met Police, Sadiq Khan and the actual government pander into this Marxist nonsense.  We'll only embolden those who did it anyway to be more brazen about it as we are seeing now. Police got called, driven off, backup was called, driven off again before more arrived.  The point is it takes time.  We heard about it when it had been going on for a while at least.  Also a street party will often run into the small hours of the night providing it is not pissing down.  It being hot or not makes little difference from street parties I have seen.  It was a nice try though but as we will see in the next few clips the copper is not having any of it so let's check it out.

Yeah I mean when I wrote about exactly these circumstances in the spectator this morning by chance predicting this kind of situation.  But the reality of it is you will get street parties, particularly in African Caribbean areas, where they will turn up in large numbers.  And because of the relationship between police and black youth, when police ask them on behalf of neighbours to be quiet and stop spoiling their life, What happens is they then turn on the police.  More police are called and eventually the police are driven away.  This is quite a regular event now in many of our housing estates around London.  And of course, the tragedy of this is it's the ordinary men and women, frankly, people like my grandmother, my grandfather, who live on the council estates who have to put up with it.

And what can be done to stop it?

Well, the only way you're going to deal with this is to have a social intervention that gets upstream and helps manage the problems that come from single parenting, particularly amongst young African-Caribbean women. I can say this is true from the things I have seen in my own life.
